33768365.review:
This game is a clear improvement on the first game.  While the tactical battle system is still lacking compared to other examples in this genre, it has been improved with even more options and units.  The strategy of beating down the strongest enemy and then leaving them alive so they can ineffectually waste turns is still valid throughout this game, though.  The story and art are still both top notch, and the music remains fantastic.  You can beat the entire game in under 15 hours, but because of the impactful story choices and the nature of the tactic based system, it has a lot of replay value.  

The story ends without resolution, which, of course, means a new Saga is sure to be released, but I love how all the meaningful choices from the first game are still present in this one, and I bet the trend continues into the third game.  After beating this game I immediately wanted to play again.  And not just this second installment, but from the start of the Saga.  Based on the plot choices alone, there seems to be insane replay value if you enjoy the combat system enough to do so.  And I do, mainly because the art is so beautiful!

33762021.review:
Отличная игра, но перед покупкой обязательно надо пройти первую часть. Одна из ключевых особенностей игры, то что абсолютно все можно перенести из первой части, а конкретно переносятся все выжившие персонажи, все ваши предметы,  количество людей и варлов в короване, очки славы и припасы. И игра стартует ровно с того момента, где закончилась первая часть. Честно, подобного не видел еще ни в одной игре. Конечно было что то похожее в масс ефекте, но там игра стартует не с того же момента, и все персонажи разбросаны по галактике..

Графика осталась на уровне, но теперь как мне показалось больше проработанных мультипликационных вставок, а в первой части их почти не было.

Сюжет тоже остался на том же уровне, то есть все так же достоин голливудского фильма вроде властелина кольца. 

Атмосфера в игре становится более загадочной и напряженной, и это круто.

Основа геймплея осталась такой же, но появились значительные изменения. Например, теперь можно тренировать сколько угодно людей в бойцов, бойцы будут сражаться, но больше жрать, обычные люди теперь занимаются охотой и собирательством, то есть добывают припасы.  В боевке же появились новые типы врагов, новые типы героев. У старых героев появилась возможность открыть вторую способность. Максимальный уровень героя повышен с 5, до 10, и добавлены таланты у персонажей. В целом боевка стала продуманей и интересней.

Музыка, вот тут как то средняк. Главная тема шедевральна, но например музыка в вживание мне вообще непонравилась, какая то дикая и не ритмичная.

Кстати добавили режим выживания, череда из 40 боев, где герои умершие в бою умирают на всегда, и число перезагрузок ограничено. Я на сложном уровне с первого раза смог дойти только почти до середины.

В целом это вообще одна из любимых игр. Тут все персонажи продуманны, большая часть может умереть, люди и варлы из корована тоже могут умереть вообще все. Много вариантов действий в разных ситуациях, и все действия реально влияют на события. Так что этой игрухе только 10 из 10.

Хотя вот есть минус, когда качаешь персонажа, и тут он умирает, а слава которую ты в него влил не возвращается. А еще прокачка персонажей, и покупка вещей в магазине делается за одну и ту же валюту, это странно.

33757567.review:
Well, them vikin boys are back at it again. Runnin around the entire world and whatnot. Really makes you think, huh? What we got here is a more refined Banner Saga 1. 

First question: would you need to buy the Banner Saga 1 to understand what happens in the Banner Saga 2?
Answer: Yes, more or less. This is a direct sequel, and I'd expect the Banner Saga 3 to follow suit. This game takes some time to spell out things, and throw in some more flavor via character bios; but if you're looking for the whole picture of what's going on, I'd recommend buying and playing the first game.

Second question: what's different this time around?
Answer: The game feels a lot more cohesive this time. Things are a bit more fleshed out comparatively to the first game in the series; and overall things seem to be a bit more thought out. Its an improvement, but the basis of the game is largely unchanged.

So, things are really heating up in banner land and the end of the world is upon us. And no walls are gonna save you when the dredge come a knockin, so sir. It was like that in the first game, but this time things seem to be spiraling downwards more rapidly than before. Viking land is all but destroyed, and anybody left is angry and hungry. It is in this great time of crisis that you are asked to lead your people to safety.

In that respect, Banner Saga 2 is exactly the same as the first game. A series of events stand in your way to the promised land. Some of them are tricky. Some of them are predictable. Others are surprising for different reasons. Now, of course, these events are scripted; and like the first game, major story beats are exactly the same no matter who you're swinging battle axes at. But the biggest difference I can tell is that the enemies of tBS2 are far more varied than before. Previously, you were either fighting dredge or raiders. This time around, everyone's out to get you; much like what would happen in a more typical apocalyptic fantasy Viking adventure. The dredge are more varied. The raiders are far less common. Different animals and beasts show up to the battle to eat you and your people before lunch on any given day. This makes the game a lot more interesting, especially from a resource management perspective. 

Your decisions actually have downsides, and I was second guessing myself sometimes as to what was the best way to do things. Wasting food, being careless with your heroes, trying to push with low morale; all of these things make the game significantly harder, which is interesting. I didn't find the game particularly hard, but I was definitely challenged by some of the battles. Some of them can be downright brutal, as this game really likes throwing waves of enemies at you. Expect to be consistently outnumbered in just about any fight. tBS2, does however reward bravery and the clever use of resources. Various bonuses can be earned throughout the game to make the game a lot less punishing. 

Overall, I was pleased with this game. In my opinion, this game is standing head and shoulders above the prequel. There's a great deal more at play here, from the battles, to the heroes, to the mechanics and the choices. Everything comes together very nicely. One complaint I do have is that the game doesn't have an ending per se, being that it's part two of three. However, I am excited about what's to come, and I'd welcome an even more improved third part to send the trilogy off with.

I recommend the game but not strongly. It has great visuals & sound and somewhat interesting combat but its storytelling part is meh. It is also overpriced especially considering that Banner Saga is essentially one story divided into three parts.

Nonetheless, the combat still feels very gamey, which undermines the story. The visuals and sound also are better. For instance, the background imagery of the journey is much more varied. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the story: unlike the first part, it lacks equally powerful ending. It also has all the problems of the first part. The story is linear and not very imaginative despite interesting lore. Many game events do not provide sufficient information for decision-making. The results of such “choices” feel arbitrary and sometimes punishing like whims of bad Game Master in PnP RPG.

33557278.review:
The sequel to Banner Saga retains all the aspects that made that game great and set it apart. Think of it as having all of the moment-to-moment decision making weight of a game like XCOM while telling you a story that's much stranger and more personal (in an odd way). Gripping story with meaningful decisions and tense tactical combat make Banner Saga 2 punch in a much higher weight class. 

Art design is unique and conveys the world's mystery/mythology and norse-like aesthetic sensibilities, while the writing is wonderfully concise, doing a really effective job of conveying character and plot in a way that's not only meaningful but clarifies the stakes in player decisions. 

The turn-based tactical combat is, as well, tense with weighty decisions. Each upgrade or skill feels useful and unique, each movement an opportunity and risk. There's no dice rolling, just execution of your (good or bad) strategy - it's really marvelous. 

Play this game! 

Note - there is at least 1 more game coming, so the ending is a bit of a cliffhanger. That said, the resolution of this narrative arc is suitably 'complicated' for the player - I don't think it's a letdown at all, but rather (and in line with the overall narrative) keeps things from descenting into a black-and-white worldview.

33375390.review:
What a sequel.  That's what I'm left thinking having recently finished my first playthrough of The Banner Saga 2.

Like the first game, The Banner Saga 2 definitely [i]feels[/i] replayable, even though I haven't yet replayed either game I definitely plan to, especially 2.  There are a number of choices I made that I would like to see play out differently.

[b]The Best Parts[/b]
[list]
  [*]Improved [b]battle gameplay[/b] (Barricades, New hero classes, Additional powers for heroes, and more!)
  [*][b]Plot[/b] drives forward with purpose, [b]great pacing[/b] (another satisfying chapter of the Saga - just the right length)
  [*]Import your save from The Banner Saga
[/list]

I could go on listing what makes The Banner Saga 2 great, but the above list summarizes the very best parts of the game.

A list of [b]The Worst Parts[/b] would be difficult to come up with.  There's one point in the game that was quite challenging for me - but if anything, that's another [b][i]pro[/i][/b] rather than a con. 33301164.review:
Just a note that when I first tried to play this, importing my Banner Saga 1 save resulted in a game that was broken in the initial tutorial and wouldn't let me progress at all. I'm not sure why that was, but since it had been so long since playing BS1 I decided to play the whole of the first game again to get a fresh save, and the second time it worked. So beware.

Once I got past that, I found that this game is essentially identical to its predecessor in terms of mechanics. Combat is the same, with armor and strength pools being targeted separately, which can require smarter use of your attacks. The caravan mechanics are the same - you move through the world, trying to keep morale and supplies up by responding properly to random events, and occasionally encounter story beats or battles to be fought. It's a simple and engaging formula that still works in a second game - I'm actually glad they didn't change much of it.

In terms of story, I think it suffers a bit from the lull typical in mid-trilogy works - half of the story splits off to follow a separate caravan populated by almost entirely new characters, and it takes a while for them to get interesting (but they do, with some really interesting story stuff going on). Meanwhile, the main caravan seems to be a little conservative with developing the protagonist's story - little wonder, given who that protagonist is depends on the end of Banner Saga 1.

But there continues to be lots of unpleasant decisions, and the occasional unexpected death, and new and interesting lore gets revealed as the game goes on. The art and music are gorgeous as usual, and the ending feels like a suitable setup to an epic conclusion. I've backed the third game on Kickstarter, so now it's just a question of waiting it out to see what happens next!

33287337.review: Эталонное продолжения эталонного фентези, которое лично для меня встало в один ряд с "Властелином колец", "Игрой престолов" и другими грандами жанра. Говорю я, разумеется, о истории. Начавшаяся в первой части сюжетная линия, о спасении небольшого отряда беженцев от надвигающегося врага, во второй разростается до решения спасения всего мира и решения глобальных вопросов. Именно в решении этих вопросов и заключается главная прелесть Banner Saga, история не линейна, это очень сильно ощущается. Одним неверным решением можно убить одного из центральных персонажей, неправильным действием можно развязать настоящую крупномасштабную войну, все это ощущается так органично и плавно, что оторваться от истории невозможно. Бои стали сложнее, сюжет накрученее (во второй части еще больший акцент ставится на лоре) а обдумывание каждого действия достигло апогея. Если вам понравилась первая часть, то без сомнений вы должны купить эту игру. Если первая часть оставила у вас смешанные чувства, то думаю что вторая не оставит вас равнодушным и вы сформируете окончательное мнение об этой серии игр. Лично для меня нет на данный момент более ожидаемой игры, чем третья часть Banner Saga, думаю, это о многом говорит. Великолепное продолжение Великой саги.

Pros:

Cons:
- Disappointingly, ridiculously short.  
- Nothing seemed to matter.  There's a click-to-converse things but I get the sense from dying and replaying through key scenes that the outcome of any interactions would result in the same story, but I might be wrong.
- The game just ends at a weird spot, I replayed what would be the final battle about four or five times thinking I'd somehow lost and had to 'win' the fight some different way to not get a miserable half-assed ending.

Worth a few bucks and good for the very short time I played it, but unless Banner Saga 3 gives a lot more value I probably won't be picking it up and can't really recommend a game that's over so fast.

32083104.review:
The whole Banner Saga franchise is a pleasure for the eyes.
The second chapter is literally a continuation of the previous one, and you somehow "must" play Banner Saga 1 in order to get everything - this episode starts at the exact point in which the previous one finished.
The gameplay is similar, but has been improved in many factors adding variety and difficulty to the combat field and the "promotion" of the warriors; now you can go over level 5 for everyone and add abilities and such.
It's still an awesome tactical role-playing game, with heavy elements of dialogue and choices which will influence everything, from the warriors you'll fight with to the scenes, to your morale and so on.
Overall, if you have played for hours and hours the first Banner Saga you'll find yourself in the same environment, and you'll get used to the new implementations.
The graphics are still awesome, even more than before with new ambientations and cinematic actions!
I'd really really recommend to anyone this game, it's perfection for a PC tactical RPG!

I liked the first game.  The story was good, I felt empathy for my characters, and the ending of the game was a surprise.  The game's graphics are good for what it is, but the combat system in both 1 and 2 can become annoying.  I am an initiative type of guy when it comes to turn based games.  I absolutely dislike doubling up on enemy turns just because.  Anyways, I started playing this game and started to feel emotionally drained.  I also found myself genuinely hating the cast of characters all of a sudden.  This game pretty much picks up where the first left off.  Having played through the first game, twice, I just felt like I have seen enough of the same.  

The battles, the walking around, I just got bored of it.  I just wanted to hit fast forward and get through the waiting around time.  Even skipping the story scenes because I legitimately didn't care.  Probably should have played through as Rook, but, the combat isn't that fun either.  The way the turn system is handled is just garbage.  Love the moves, the strategy, the animations, but the turn system ruins it.  Not turn based, don't get that confused with how the system was designed.  There are games where your sides take turns, games where initiative scores are taken into account, games where dice rolls are added on top of initiative, games where weight effects your initiative, and then this game.  You move 1, they move 1.  No matter what.  You have 10 guys, they have 2?  You move your warrior next to him.  He hits your warrior.  You move archer on the other side of the map, he kills your warrior.  You move dude close to him, he hits dude you just moved.  You move other archer on the other side of the map, he finishes off the guy he just hit.  See where this goes?  

Overall, the music, sounds, artwork, and story are good.  Though, I just became uninterested in the story.  I also became uninterested in the combat, which became more annoying than it was challenging.  My friends won't touch games like this.  But if you like story games, and strange combat systems, then this game might be for you.

31717845.review:
※この作品は日本語字幕に対応しています。

The Banner Saga 三部作の二作品目。（07年5月現在：Kickstarterでの資金獲得に成功し現在The Banner Saga 3は開発中です）
続き物ですので、The Banner Saga 1からのプレイを強くおすすめします。
前作のセーブデータがある場合は引き継ぎができます。（引き継がない場合でも、あらすじを見たり、2の導入部分からも開始もできます）

あなたの選択も引き継がれ、あなたの物語（サーガ）は続く。

世界を覆い尽くさんとする闇、邪悪な化物、謎のメンダー（魔法使い）、立ちふさがるドレッジ、広がる謎。前作から続くこの物語では、更に世界の終わりや迫る謎を感じられ、物語は終盤へ向けて加速していきます。

このゲームは、前作と同じくあなたの選択とその代償を噛みしめるゲームとなっています。
あなたはただ偶然が重なり、計らずも英雄として担ぎ上げられた、ただの一般人ですが仲間のため民のため、安住の地を目指し歩み続けます。
キャラバンを率いて「生き残る」ために行軍しているあなたは、多くの決断を迫られることでしょう。

あなたの決断一つで、あなたを慕いあなたを守ろうと斧を掲げた仲間が殺され、ただの肉塊になる事もあり得るのです。
仲間を守るために物資を犠牲にする？ 物資を守るために仲間とともに危険を承知で敵に立ち向かう？ 危険を承知で仲間に斥候に出す？
襲われている村を助ける？ 待ち伏せを警戒して先を急ぐ？ 助けを求める難民を受け入れる？ 襲ってきた敵の命を見逃してやる？ 

すべての選択肢は、あなたの物語（サーガ）に紡がれていくことでしょう。

キャラバンはさまさまな種族や人種、仲間たちで構成されていますが、仲間であるはずのキャラバンですら多くの問題を抱えています。
世界の終わりが迫っているこの時代で、「誰かを犠牲にしなければ、誰かを守ることができない」こともあります。
善意から助けた難民たちに寝首をかかれることもあるかもしれません。誰を信じ、誰を疑い、何をすべきなのか、決めるのはあなたなのです。

[キャラバンについて]
大規模戦がなくなりました。
民間人は食料を定期的に採集してきてくれるため、民間人を多く確保することにもメリットが生まれました。
あなたが必要だと判断すれば、キャンプで民間人を戦士に鍛え上げることもできるので必要に応じて訓練するか考えましょう。

[バトル関連]
交互に1人ずつキャラを動かすシステムは前作と同じ。
新しく人馬と呼ばれるケンタウルスのような種族や、意志力を支援するポエット（詩人）など新しいクラスも追加され戦闘に幅が出ました。
防御がある間はすべて防御でダメージを受けるという特性をもったキャラクターもいるため、防御を活かした戦い方も実用的に。

レベルキャップも10まで引き上げられ、ステータスもカンストさせると更にボーナスとしてパッシブスキルを習得できるようになりました。
レベル6まであげるとサブスキルを習得できるようになったためキャラを育てる楽しみも増えました。

[不満点]
行軍中の速度、戦闘中の移動速度などのもっさり感は相変わらず。
繰り返しプレイする時などはストレスに感じると思います。

セーブするタイミングがわかりにくい。オートセーブ、チャプターセーブのみのこのゲームの特徴ですがタイミングが計りづらいため場合によってはセーブされていなくて…ということもあるため不便

31665312.review:
This game suffers from the fact that it's the middle game between an intended 3 part series. You know how whenever there's a movie franchise that splits the last movie into 2 parts and the first part always feels kinda flat because you know nothing really is going to happen that's significant anyway? Well that's kind of how Banner Saga 2 feels like. It keeps on building and building to something and when it ends you're left unsatisfied. 

Only when it does end do you realize how actually little actually happened in this game, so little that they had to make it so 50% of the time you're not even controlling the character from the first game (Rook or his daughter) instead you control another Varl who I think was in the first game but you really have NO connection with at all. In fact the game does this at least another time, where you can pick dialogue choices from other side characters which is really jarring and immersion breaking because why are you deciding what all these other characters are saying or doing all of a sudden? It was so weird. 

Also, for those hoping that there would be some decent character development between Rook and Oddlief I guess they didn't really put too much effort into it because half the time he would've been dead in this game but I'm not entirely kidding it felt like that the amount of conversations they have towards anything romance related I can count on a mutated hand that only had 3 fingers. One in the beginning, one at the end, and maybe one in the middle I possibly missed but I'm pretty sure I didn't.

I don't normally write reviews but based on how much I loved the first game I feel I have to vote: everything I have to say is covered in other, more detailed negative reviews:

There's a few typos that further the impression that the devs weren't paying as much attention this time.

Your victory objectives aren't explained so yeah, there really is a few battles you have to lose first in order to figure out what you should've done.

You have the option to train plenty of fighters but you don't need them (for anything).

The ending absolutely sucked. You're given the impression you'll get something if you do a particular thing (it's explained to you "The lightning might...") but it doesn't and you don't. You might as well just fight like normal and save yourself an hour.

It feels as if the last half of the game is just "You know, we could probably make a Banner Saga 3."

Might buy 3 if it's on sale but I won't pay more than $5 until the devs prove they aren't just in it for the shekels.

My verdict: another great indie series ruined by greed.

31034836.review:
Как же не хватает в Steam нейтральной оценки. Эта игра - просто образцовый пример одновременно и халтуры и гениальности.

Здесь просто великолепнейший сюжет, очень оригинальная концепция мира, неожиданные и, главное, логичные, сюжетные повороты, которые порой заставляют сердце ёкнуть. Здесь опять же неповторимый геймплей - подход к боевке прост и уникален - очередность ходов, урон в прямой зависимости от хп - гениальная находка. Здесь, наконец, великолепнейший OST, который можно слушать вечно.

Но! Здесь же и невообразимая лень и халтура. Вторая часть, которую, к слову, пилили аж два года, от первой не отличается ничем, кроме диалогов. Вот серьёзно, ребята, что вы эти два года делали? Писали диалоги? Во всем остальном игра вообще такая же как и первая часть - и графически, и геймплейно. Да даже арты большинства персонажей перерисовать никто не удосужился. Все таки хотелось бы хоть какого-то развития. Те же Telltale эпизоды к уже вышедшим своим сериалам выпускаеют за пару месяцев. Вы же тут два года, да еще и с кикстартером, рожали.

И, чуть не забыл, отдельные лучи поноса за локализацию на русский язык с задержкой в год.

Но всё-таки, оценка будет положительной. Потому что сюжет, атмосфера, музыка.

The Banner Saga 2 sigue muy de cerca lo visto en la primera parte, expandiendo la jugabilidad por el camino con unas cuantas nuevas opciones, especialmente las relacionadas con la nueva raza jugable. En este sentido, no se puede decir que The Banner Saga 2 sea un juego muy original ni innovador, pero sigue siendo un muy buen juego de estrategia por turnos, con una historia que continúa y desarrolla lo visto en la parte anterior y que mantiene con mucha facilidad el interés.

A nivel gráfico el juego es muy bonito, especialmente en los decorados y escenarios, que realmente son capaces de transmitir con mucha eficacia y elegancia la estética y el ambiente del juego. A nivel de sonido el juego cumple bastante bien también, especialmente en la banda sonora y las voces, ya que los efectos pueden ser algo repetitivos.

En resumen, realmente es una continuación muy fiel al original, de modo que gustará especialmente a los que disfrutaron del primero; si no es tu caso, probablemente vale la pena que juegues al anterior antes, para ver la historia desde su comienzo. Un 7.

30673450.review:
I haven't played the regular game at all because I remember the first Banner Saga's strange interpretation of "turn order". While innovative, it's also counter-intuitive, with generally the best strategy being to maim everything in sight but not finish off any particular opponent. I'm not crazy about constructing a barrier out of crippled foes while I plink away at their health back ranks, but thankfully, the second iteration of this game very nearly scratches my squad-tactics itch. My main interest is the (mostly) deterministic turn-based combat. It's really refreshing to play a game with deep tactics that doesn't rely on chance to provide a dynamic challenge. The armor/strength system is simple but brilliant and rewards careful planning and execution. So yes, full disclosure: I've bascially only played survival mode, but I've played a lot of it. If you like turn-based tactics, and don't like random-number-generated tension, I'd have to recommend this one, because it's about the only thing like it. (Incidentally, if you're reading this review and know of another game like this, particularly one that doesn't have the problem mentioned below, leave a comment and you'll have my deep gratitude.)

So I've got only one gripe, but it's a pretty significant one: The game is turn-based, but there is a turn-timer, and there is no way to pause. It's also single-player only, by the way. On top of that, the interface is a bit clunky; meaning that assessing the potential movement of an enemy takes several seconds, and if there are several enemies, it's pretty easy to run out of time and completely miss a character's turn. Don't try to wait to the last second assessing your options because any action requires several clicks to choose and confirm. It is frustrating to warrant the negative review in my opinion, although, as previously mentioned, if you're having trouble finding a game that throws that stupid d20 in the trash where it mostly belongs, try this one, you might have a different opinion.

I think the timer is motivated by the notion of "leaderboards". For what it's worth, I'm one of those people who couldn't give a frog's fart for how I stack up against other people in a turn-based tactical game. Well... I guess that's not completely true: I also play a lot of internet chess on FICS and pay some attention to my rating, so yeah... But still, I'd be elated if only there were a "hardcore" mode with ticking turn-timers and the like, but also a "sissy" mode for folks like me who enjoy turn-based tactics because of it's player-defined pacing.

Anyways, if that silly timer could be disabled (it can't and this game doesn't support mods), I would give this game a REALLY enthusiastic thumbs up, solely on the basis of the survival minigame. I'm sure the main game is lovely too, if you're into that story, character development and meaningful decisions sort of thing. I kind of leave that stuff for books, movies, and the cereal aisle, but hey, whatever floats your boat.

30664894.review:
I could just look at this game for hours. This is exactly the kind of game that plays perfectly on a tablet (mechanics focus on strategy, not reflexes; story is engaging, but never drags on for more than a minute without prompting a choice or action), but... Play it on the best monitor you have if you can it's absolutely worth it.

The narrative itself does not wrap up as tightly as the first game, but mostly in the sense that they were obviously a lot more confident in the sequel happening than they were with the first instalment and they can afford the unresolved ending. Definitely looking forward to TBS3!

If I had one critique, it would be the treatment of music during combat scenes. The scoring overall is great, but the combat loop just repeats without variation. While you might not notice as you plan your next four moves, I can attest to the fact that the repeating audio will drill into the brain of anyone else in the room until you are compelled to find a headset...

30623166.review:
I really loved this game and it scratched my itch for a proper RPG style tale in a computer format. To get the most out of it I recommend playing it with a role-playing mindset, that is what made it a great experience for me, trying to get under the skin of the character you are playing and make choices based on what that person would do, not what you think would get most XP for. Min-maxing party membership and other stuff is important to many people and they get their chance to enjoy their thing, but it is not required to complete the game fully.

+ The setting, the story: Great stuff, some innovative storytelling right there. Trying to survive during Ragnarok is good material for dramatic tension.
+ Animation: I for one love the animation on the battlefield, the little manuevers the characters perform, the little dances, the gestures. I think the animation was top-notch and a important part of the game.
+ The sound: From soundtrack to voiceacting it was really well done and suited the atmosphere of the game.
+ The different perspective: Playing as the Ravens was a nice touch and the different approaches between a somewhat naive Alette and a cynical Borkverk was great fun to play out. 
+ Artstyle: The characters, the backgrounds, the fallen gods, you name it. 

 The battle mechanics are serviceable but not great, the animations made me enjoy them a lot even so and I had more fun fighting in this game than in Banner Saga 1 wich has the same mechanics. 

Overall I give this game a 9/10, though keep in mind I came for the roleplaying and the story, and I got exactly what I wanted.

30371265.review:
Banner Saga 2 feels and plays almost exactly like the first installment of the series, which is both a good and a bad thing. On the plus side, it is still an amazingly beautiful game; on the negative side, it still suffers from an incredibly stupid battle system.

To give a quick recap, in the world of the Banner Saga a characters' hit points is also equal to the amount of damage they can dish out. An uncommon yet interesting concept - which is completely ruined by one major flaw: your party and the enemies will always alternate turns.
If an enemy is killed, the next in line will simply take their position; this means that the optimal strategy to win is usually to beat down each enemy to its health minimum and then move on to the next opponent until the battlefield is filled with cripples. Conversely, this means that saving your own injured characters is a tactical disadvantage.
It also results in the absurd fact that battles are generally the easier the bigger the enemy army, as they will waste turns moving with far away characters while you can maim everything next to your guys with no resistance. As an unfortunate side-effect this drains atmosphere from the story, as the approaching giant army of Dredge hardly seems like a menace.

Granted, the developer has apparently realized how stupid their system is, and introduced a number of new talents and features which punish not killing enemies, allow for turn order manipulation, or outright alter/replace the combat system. Is it enough to save Banner Saga 2's merit as a strategy game? No. Which is sad, because it is a great narrative experience.

That said, there's a few other things about the game I found annoying, but also a few improvements compared to its predecessor:

Positive:
- more detailed and varied battlefields
- battlefields which are just squares are less common
- finally a decent variety of enemies

Negative:
- The ending. It is weak from a story standpoint, but gameplay-wise it plain sucks. None of the last few battles are challenging, and the final one is just a dumb gimmick involving no strategy
- Choices are oftentimes mundane, and choosing anything that involves your lead character almost always nets the best result without any danger
- You still made a bad choice and lost clansmen? Hard to care since they're little more but numbers on the top of the screen, serving even less purpose than before
- Inconsistent character sprites. One can clearly distinguish old and new character models (the old ones have a more grey outline, while the newer ones are black); some such as Rook have some animation frames with both, and it looks really patchy once you have noticed it for the first time
- RNG is a bigger factor due to numerous new talents which have a % chance to do something
- The game does a lot of "tell" but little "show". An epic confrontation between Eyvind and the world-eating Serpent just happened? Here, enjoy this still image of guys standing around and talking about how amazing it was.

Conclusion:
A bit better than the first installment, but Banner Saga 2 is another pass. Sadly.

30361330.review:
The Banner Saga 2 is the second game in the Banner Saga trilogy (the third part being currently in development), and is basically more of the same, but with several improvements. It tells the tale of a few human and Varl, trying desperately to survive in a norse mythology based world on the brink of total collapse. The story follows two separate, but intertwined routes. One is a clan leader, trying to lead a caravan of his clansmen to the relative safety of the human capital, Arberrang. The second is Bolverk, a ruthless Varl mercenary on a quest from one of the mysterious Valka (sort of a human wizard). Both will face hard choices en route, and both will suffer the consequences. Essentialy, the gameplay comes down to three things. First is managing your caravan, making sure your clansmen are safe, happy and have enough to eat. This involves dealing with various events along the way, which is the second part of the fun. Every situation you encounter comes with a choice. It is sometimes difficult to tell what is the best course of action, and consequences can be dire - including the death of key characters. Third part of the gameplay are the tactical battles. So, here is a breakdown on what is done right and what needs some rework.

The Good:
+ The atmosphere of this game is incredible. Both the music and the gorgeous, hand drawn graphics make you feel engrossed in the game and the desperate struggle for survival of its heroes
+ Battles are improved compared to the first game. The enemies are much more varied this time around instead of the endless sea of Dredge in the first game. The battle maps are also much more interesting, since they now have destructible obstacles and choke points.
+ Added survival mode is loads of fun if you like the combat system. With the whole roster of characters available to choose from for your party, there are a lot of possible ways of approaching the combat. I recommend targeting some of the achievements for an additional challenge.
+ Saves carry over from the previous edition. Because of this, you can play as two different main characters, depending on the choices from the first game.
+ Choices have real consequences. Sometimes, they are really difficult to predict, so you feel just as lost as the main character, trying to do the right thing and often failing.

The Mediocre:
~ Sometimes, the options presented to the player are very similar, which makes it frustrating when you feel you have chosen the option slightly better suited to the character, yet get punished for it.
~ We're at the second game, and there are still more questions than answers. I am beginning to fear that the third game will not have enough time to resolve everything in a satisfactory manner. Hopefully that will not be the case.
~The interface is a bit clunky. This is especially true in the character screen. I get that this was done deliberately so that the game could work on touch screens and consoles, but come on, some streamlining for PC cannot be all that hard.

The Bad:
- Renown, the rather scarce main resource of the game, is tied to steam achievements. Each time you finish an achievement, you receive a certain amount of renown. I have two problems with this. First of all, it is easy to screw up. Hard. So, you'd probably want to load... and thus lose the renown for, say, killing 3 enemies with a certain character, which you managed to do just before loading. I get that this is done to encourage playing the game to the end without using saves and maybe trying another playthrough with other choices. This leads me to number two. If you are planning on a second playthrough, you are basically hindered from the start, since you will NOT gain any more renown from the achievements. And it is a significant amount - you could probably level a character from 5 to 10 for it, which is huge.
- Still no 'Undo move' in combat. This is incredibly frustrating. Many times I have moved a character only to find out I was out of range for an attack by one square or had to reload the whole battle due to a simple misclick.

TL;DR - Great game with an incredible atmosphere, consequence heavy choices and interesting combat. A must have if you played the first part. If you did not like Banner Saga 1, do not bother with this one either.

30184925.review:
Did you like Banner Saga?
Yes?
Good. Banner Saga 2 is as much a direct sequel as can be expected. A few improvements here and there, though a notable absence of improvements the first game sorely needed (such as being able to undo your movements in tactical combat). It imports your save game directly from Banner Saga 1 and picks up where it left off. This results in you possibly starting out with wildly different parties, Renown (XP) and item layouts. 

The overarching story is just as obtuse as the first game's, if not more, though what matters is the journey, the Oregon Trail-like traversing of beautiful landscapes and the challenges you find along the way, rather than the obscure main plot. The characters are dry and straightforward, and yet, I don't know how they do it, they manage to give surprising depth to many characters that barely have five spoken lines in the entire game. It's rather heartening.

As with the first game, Banner Saga 2 ends on a cliffhanger and rather obvious sequel hook. I have little to complain about this stupendous game. The art is beautiful, the music is stirring, the combat is tactical and fun, the worldbuilding is fascinating. You can be sure I'll grab the third one when it comes out.

29952671.review:
Ich habe Banner Saga 1 und 2 innerhalb von 3 Tagen durchgespielt. Nachdem mich die Spiele einmal eingefangen hatten, konnte ich nicht mehr aufhören.
Daran erkennt man vielleicht schon, dass mir die Spiele sehr gefallen haben, jedoch habe ich auch einige Kritikpunkte:

Die Spiele erzählen eine packende Story in wunderschöner gezeichneter Atmosphäre. Die Musik ist für die Größe der Titel und des Entwicklerteams eigentlich schon zu teuer, das ist jedoch ein großer Pluspunkt im ansonsten recht stummen Spiel. Ich habe beide Spiele für jeweils 20 EUR Vollpreis gekauft und jeweils 8-9 h Spielzeit herausbekommen, was einem reichen kann oder auch nicht, vielleicht wartet man besser, bis es beide in einer Art Bundle im Sale bekommt. Denn außer der (wirklich guten) Storyline gibt es nicht viel, was die Spiele sonst noch bieten (wobei im zweiten Teil ein Überlebensmodus hinzugefügt wurde, wobei ich nicht denke, dass dieser mich viel Spielzeit kosten wird). Natürlich kann man jederzeit die Story wiederholen und versuchen, andere Entscheidungen zu treffen, aber wie oft man das durchziehen kann, bis man bei jeder Entscheidung weiß, was die beste Antwortmöglichkeit ist, ist vermutlich an einer Hand abzuzählen.
Obwohl ich dachte, ich würde hauptsächlich ein turn-based strategy game kaufen, erhielt ich für die meiste Zeit einen Mix aus Ressourcenmanagement und Visual Novel. Dies klingt abwertend, soll es aber gar nicht sein, denn die meiste Zeit im Spiel verbringt man damit, eine Karawane durch ein von Krieg geplagtes Land kurz vor der Apokalypse zu führen. Hierbei schafft es das Spiel unglaublich gut, das Gefühl, ein echter Anführer zu sein, der für hunderte Leute verantwortlich ist, zu übertragen. Durch die kurzen Ladezeiten und ständigen Bewegung der Karawane (bis man mit einer Entscheidung konfrontiert wird) hat man immer etwas zu tun. Selbst während der Rastzeiten muss man seine Helden managen und versuchen, genug Vorräte ranzuschaffen und die Moral hoch zu halten.
Die Entscheidungen sind der Mittelpunkt des Spiels. Wer hier einen Fehler begeht, kann auch schnell mal einen bis dahin beliebten Hauptcharakter versterben lassen, der dann auch wirklich tot ist. Außerdem kann man Karawanenmitglieder und Krieger verlieren, was ebenso am Ego nagt. Die wenigen guten Nachrichten zwischendurch sind dann immer ein Grund zur Freude.
Umso schlimmer ist es, dass die deutsche Lokalisation es manchmal sehr schwierig macht, gezielt Entscheidungen zu treffen. Während der generelle Wortlaut sehr gut ist, merkt man dem Spiel an, dass jede Zeile einzeln übersetzt und nicht auf den Kontext geachtet wurde. So stellt man fest, dass Wörter plötzlich in einer Frage anders übersetzt wurden, als in der Antwort. Manchmal scheint eine Entscheidungsoption durch den deutschen Wortlaut ein Witz zu sein, die sich dann jedoch als Verhöhung des Gegenüber herausstellt. 
Das alles vermiest ein wenig das Erlebnis und schadet der Immersion.

Banner Saga 2 ist hierbei bei weitem schlimmer als der erste Teil, der weitgehend verständlich war. In Part 2 fällt jedoch auch auf, dass immer mehr Rechtschreib- und Grammatikfehler vorkommen, einmal hatte ich anscheinend zufällige Sonderzeichen am Ende einer Zeile, dann mitten in einem deutschen Text einen englischen Ausdruck. Dies sind kleine Dinge, die jedoch großen Schaden anrichten.

Das Kampfsystem ist dann anders: Hier fühlt man sich, obwohl es an sich natürlich ein rundenbasiertes langsames Kampfsystem ist, urplötzlich stärker gefordert. Man muss überdenken, wie man seine Helden positioniert, welche Gegner die gefährlichsten sind und wie man einen Kampf möglichst gut dominiert. Diese Gefechte sind für mich die stärksten Momente im Spiel und hätten ruhig öfter vorkommen dürfen.

Ansonsten irritiert mich nur die Sprachausgabe, die auf englisch gehalten ist, jedoch nur sehr vereinzelt vorkommt. Im zweiten Teil habe ich den Sprecher meines Hauptcharakters gar nicht mehr gehört, der im ersten Teil noch oft zu Wort kam. Warum man sich hier nicht entschieden hat, komplett auf's Einsprechen zu verzichten, weiß ich nicht.

Ansonsten sind The Banner Saga und The Banner Saga 2 für mich auf jeden Fall empfehlenswert für jeden Spieler, der ein wenig Geduld hat. Ich selbst war neu im turn-base strategy, doch diese Spiele sind gute Einsteigertitel in diesem Genre.

1) Right click Banner Saga 2 in your Steam Library
2) Click on Properties
3) Navigate to the “BETAS” tab
4) Use the dropdown menu to select “localization” branch
5) Download the Update
6) Launch Banner Saga 2

29609898.review:
Я проходил залпом - Banner Saga 1 и сразу после нее Banner Saga 2. 

Возможно, поэтому ощущение от начала игры было не самое хорошее. Глуповатые диалоги, вплетающие обучающие элементы в историю, немножко расстроили. Они не имели ничего общего с потрясными репликами первой части. Да и сюжет в начале игры в целом просел (примерно как в середине первой части). Однако, если перетерпеть - то вскоре начинается годнота.  

Ещё появилось ощущение что персонажей искуственно наплодили. Наплодили так, что за время игры и при таком повествовании у них просто нет шансов раскрыться. Тем не менее, персонажи хорошо проработаны, необычны и просто интересны. 

История в паре мест удивила. Да, до части событий или фактов допедриваешь раньше чем они поясняются, но всё же сюрпризы были. И они были восхитительны. 

Боёвка не стала драматично глубже, но её всё же расширили. Тактики поприбавилось :)

В целом это отличное повествование, которое я бы не прочь посмотреть в формате полнометражного мультфильма в такой же стилистике. Ну а теперь - жду третью часть, на которую уже наскребли бабла на кикстартере.

29603034.review:
Hi zusammem,

Vorneweg Teil1 hatte mich damals sehr überrascht. Man kann diese Art Spiele leicht übersehen und sich anhand der Comicart Screenshots schnell abwenden und sich sagen es gibt sicher soviel besseres.... doch wenn ihr das macht wie ich erst bei Teil 1 vor 2 Jahren glaub ich zumindest macht ihr einen Fehler.... zumindest wenn ihr gute nordisch inspirierte Fantasy-Storys mögt!!

Nun zu Teil2: 
Was wie ich finde immer ein Pluspunkt ist man setzt seine eigene!! Geschichte und die Entscheidungen die man traf auf Wunsch fort. Wie man sich in Teil1 entschied wird in Teil2 übernommen. Im Kern wie bei z.B. Mass Effect nur weniger umfangreich. Wiederspielwert deshalb auch vorhanden!
Teil 2 ist erneut eine Story geworden, dieses "ich will unbedingt wissen wie es weitergeht"-Gefühl gibts nicht so oft bei Games denke ich. Das Konzept des ersten Teils wird fortgeführt und erweitert. Durch neue Klassen wird das Kampfsystem vielseitiger, durch Talente die Charakterentwicklung individueller. Klar wie immer bei ner Fortsetzung fehlt einem etwas das Gefühl etwas komplett neues anzugehen aber denke das ist eher normal. Und wie immer hat man viel zu wenig Anerkennung und muss sich entscheiden, ob einem Charakterstufen, Items oder Verpflegung wichtiger sind. Schon knifflig bisweilen aber darum gehts ja ;). Klar auf den Grafikstil muss man sich einlassen, aber selbst als bekennde "Grafikhure" konnte ichdem Artwork am Ende etwas abgewinnen. Ästhetisch und es passt einfach, genau wie der Sound. Herrlich das Spiel blutet Atmosspäre wie man so schön sagt und ich für meinen Teil wurde in diese Welt hineingezogen. Fand die Geschichte wirklich toll, nur ohne zuviel zu verraten, das Ende war etwas plötzlich und für meinen Geschmack zu kurz, aber Teil3 soll ja kommen. Also Daumen hoch wenn ihr Teil1 mochtet, Fantasyfan seid oder einfach gute Storys mögt.... aber wer nicht gerne Texte liest oder auf Daueraction pur abfährt, der lässt eher die Finger davon. Hoffe ich konnt euch helfen bei der Kaufentscheidung. VG und Skål

29531691.review:
Banner Saga 1 & 2 & 3(probably) have filled a large hole in my heart that was left by Final Fantasy Tactics no longer continuing their series after Grimoire. Wonderful art, cool music (great for hiking in the winter/fall), fun tactics, and interesting decisions that reward and punish you in ways unexpected. 

A great deal of games boast decision making being a big part of the game fail to do so. Typically they give you just 3 options; one obviously good, one obviously bad, and one neutral and the ending they present is just shows you made the world a better or worse place. In this game you can make a good guy decision and it pays off wonderfully like a new unit or something game changing resource, or nothing at all. Sometimes doing what you think is right ends up with one of your key characters getting his throat slit and never being able to play him again. 

I have played both Banner Sagas many times in many different ways and it is always rewarding. If you like myth, morals, viking aged warriors, and a game that really pulls you in I highly recommend this and the first one. 

There is even an online pvp version of this game that for whatever reason isn't publicized as much called Banner Saga Factions. It was released with the first game and hopefully they will update with Bannersaga 2 and 3 mechanics. It's alright but it is free to play.

29528610.review:

29527740.review:
[b]The Banner Saga 2 is a story driven RPG with turn based combat in a engaging and apocalyptic viking fantasy.[/b] 

I found the story and art work to be beautiful and well writen as they were in the first game but in the sequal many systems are impoved and fleshed out, with TBS2 you get the feeling the Devs really hit there stride with TBS series.
In most every way The Banner Saga 2 is even better than TBS 1, also many hours of great strategy gameplay can be had with the additon of survival mode on top of the core game. The Survival Mode was released as a free patch from Stoic.
"Survival Mode" is a 40 map back to back challenge for your party along with the new skills & talents is a huge bonus if you like the in depth turn based strategy combat system.

About the combat system: I learned the TBS combat system is about monitoring the order of battle and clicking on th enemy units to show there range of movment so you can predict the AI's next moves - like chess some battles you must look several moves ahead to win. There is an ellement of RNG to what enemy units you face on a given map but most if not all battles can be won given the right strategy.

(They have a deal atm, if you kickstart TBS3 you can pay 20$ and get the first 2 games as well if you are looking to buy the series and save a few bucks.)

29417004.review:
Großartiges RPG im Stil  Final Fantasy Tactics oder Front Mission. Wer diese beiden Serien mochte, dem wird auch Banner Saga gefallen.

+tolle 2D Optik und herausragender Sound
+sehr interessante Story und teilweise interessante Charaktere
+Gameplay ist einfach zu erlernen und schwer zu meistern + Suchtfaktor
+Dialoge mit Optionen und teilweise deutlichen Konsequenzen
+Schwierigkeitsgrade besser als im ersten Teil. Damals war leicht = mittel, mittel = schwer und schwer = ultra
Jetzt ist leicht auch für Anfänger ohne große Probleme machbar und Mittel für geübte Spiele gut machbar.
Schwer ist eine echte Herausforderung, aber hier wird persönlicher Skill und Umsicht belohnt. Kein Dark Souls Faktor.

-Game of Thrones Faktor: So ziemlich jeder Charakter kann sterben wenn man nicht aufpasst - oder Guides liest
-relativ kurze Spieldauer. In 7 Stunden habe ich es durchgespielt, ungeübte Spieler brauchen 10-15 Stunden,
allerdings kann man es danach nochmal spielen und dabei andere Entscheidungen treffen und andere Chars nutzen.
-praktisch keine Sidequests und in der Story gibt es meistens nur eine entweder/oder Wahl und man kann nie wieder
 in eine Stadt, in der man bereits war zurückkehren um dort Sachen und Essen zu kaufen was echt super wäre weil in
jeder Stadt andere Ausrüstung angeboten wird, die ich mir vielleicht zu dem Zeitpunkt nicht leisten kann, aber später.
-keine DLCs mit zusätzlichen Missionen oder neuen, interessanten Orten bzw. Charakteren
-Einige Charakteren, die keiner wirklich braucht weil sie kaum Dialoge haben oder deren Skills teilweise 
identisch sind mit anderen Charakteren (Gunnulf /Sigbjorn, Hogun / Mogun usw.).
-Man kann nicht alle Charaktere maxen, weil man die Währung dafür auch für Ausrüstungsgegenstände und
Essen braucht. Es gibt keine Möglichkeit außerhalb der Story und 6x im Trainingslager Währung zu erhalten.
Das reicht leider vorne und hinten nicht, selbst auf Leicht ist es immer noch zu knapp.

Obgleich es nach eher einer ausgewogenen Kritik aussieht, mag ich dieses Spiel wirklich und erwarte
sehnsüchtig den 3. und hoffentlich einen 4. Teil. Mehr Videosequenzen und gesprochene Dialoge wären toll :)

29386033.review:
I really liked playing The Banner Saga 1 and this game continues the saga in best tradition. Its kind of more off the same which works perfectly fine for me. If you did like the first game you will like this, no doubt. I really recommend playing the first game before, otherwise you will miss so much of the very well written story and won't understand all the fine and humorous hints. Besides all the positive aspects, i liked the first one more. Part of it is, that it really felt like nothing, that i played before (e.g. the brutal consequences you get when you make the "wrong" decision, which really made me play the game like 3-4times through to get all the chrakters and try to keep them alive:)). In the first game i also had a deeper connection to the characters, who are  gradually introduced and refined. In this game you start with a packed rooster of characters and it is difficult to choose whom to pick, i liked the limitation in the first game. Now every time i think, hmm whom i wanna pick and then just take the strongest (in my opinion). There are new (and powerful) characters introduced so you have lots of variety to choose from. The ending as a real fan of the series was very surprising and i didnt like it, but that's personal taste i guess.
All that said, start with the first game then play this, you will lke/love them both. They are  one of a kind and very fair priced for all that you get. Buy them and support the great developer so the can continue this great series.

29366493.review:
The Banner Saga 2 - продолжение, как ни странно, 1-й Саги. Разрабатывали ее бла бла бла, издали ее бла бла бла. Ненавижу эту часть обзоров, серьезно. Все и так прекрасно знают, что это за игра, а издателя и разработчика могут взять и посмотреть. Поэтому я просто напишу свои ощущения от игры.
Начну с того, что игра является некоронованным шедевром. Игра действительно шикарна, да, она чем-то хуже 1-й части, но чем-то и лучше 1-й части. В конце концов разные игры одной серии должны отличаться, разве нет? 1-я часть была более драматичной, было много грустным моментов. Над концовкой я вообще ревел. Во 2-й же части драмы как таковой нет, но здесь есть то, что делает эту игру особенной - тревога, чувство постоянной тревоги. На протяжении всей игры мне правда казалось, что вот-вот меня нагонят Драги(или как их там, я уже забыл) и дадут по башке. Постоянно казалось, что они идут со мной нога в ногу и что мне нужно делать все быстрее и быстрее. Либо это у меня паранойя развилась, либо разработчики правда сумели воссоздать эту атмосферу преследования. Всё же надеюсь, что 2-е. Игра не дает вообще избавиться от этой тревоги. Вот вроде бы ты подходишь к городу, думаешь, что сейчас передохнешь, ан нет, этот город не так прост. Еще мне очень сильно понравилось взросление, в плане лидера, главного героя. Не знаю, как за Руком, но за *имядевки*(забыл как ее зовут) было интересно наблюдать. Новый игровой персонаж - берсерк - мне не понравился, слишком он обычный для такой игры. В общем, игра удалась.
P.S Грабить корованы нельзя, но могут ограбить твой! (да, куда уж без шутки про корованы то)
P.P.S Хватит ныть по поводу русской локализации. Есть русификатор от ЗоГ, уж поверьте, если бы был официальный перевод, то перевод от ЗоГ был бы в миллиарды раз лучше. И это не пустые слова, такая же ситуация была и с 1-й частью.

29353693.review:
Better in so many ways than it’s parent, The Banner Saga 2 is a gripping, tense and inspiring experience.
I must have taken screenshots every 5 minutes – the art is fantastic. Every landscape is a wonder to behold and this beautiful world is a great backdrop to the terrifying, cruel and desperate things unfolding in it.
Playing the game felt like Star Wars without a guaranteed happy ending, with death-defying odds, plot twists, tough decisions, soul-gripping soundtrack and engaging writing. Be ready to sweat and worry, as you try to keep your characters alive, no joke.
If the tough combat gets too challenging and you’re not a fan of deep strategy or tactics – no worries. Change the difficulty to Easy and enjoy the game – you don’t need to be a chess master to play this.
Taking in to consideration all of the above, I’d say that The Banner Saga 2 has something for everyone. I highly recommend it – give this experience a try and you’ll be surprised how easily it will grow on you.

29324363.review:
If you haven't played BannerSaga 1 this game will leave you scratching your head.

If you did like me and had a gripes with the boring way they implemented the turn-based system and "forced" difficulty by stripping you of freedom (choosing certain units, making decisions unclear, unclear battle map etc) and unsatisfying ending/cliffhanger this will leave you scratching your head times 2.

While it retained the impeccable artstyle, soundtrack and story it exacerbated everything I didn't like about the first part:
Unclear decisions had me scratching my head
The Battlefield is even more obstructed, sometimes you can't even see your units blocked by foreground art.
Fights that force you to take certain types of units you don't like or are "gimped" (aka forced difficulty)

Training tent can now give you alot of resources if you complete the challenges but again, it is a challenge you can't overcome  with your wits/units, no no, the developer chooses for you. Most of the challenges are there to teach you of certain aspects/interaction between units but in a "real" battle you would never use them, why position/wait for dozens of turns for one cool thing to happen when you can just kill most of the enemies before they reach you.

I still love the interaction and characters, how they present themselves, the lore and tales. I switched to easy midgame and just zombied through the fights (which there are too much of). 

Nothing much will change I guess for the last chapter, I will play it for sure but I have serious doubts this developer can put together compelling encounters that do not rely on gimmicks.

If you got hooked on the world/lore/characters in the first part, this game is for you.

29306462.review:
BS 2 is the direct sequel to Banner Saga, who would have thought. The game continues seemlessly where you left off after Act 1. Depending on your final choice and how you skilled and equipped your heroes, the game starts you off with 1 of 2 protagonists. Items and level stay the same and can now be increased further up to level 10. The core gameplay remains 100% the same, so it's a waste of time to be talking about that again. Instead I'll give you the changes and improvements:

- THREE branching storylines instead of TWO, depending on who leads the caravan: Rook or Alette (though this is only relevant in 4 chapters or so and does not change the overall story, just the individual's, i.e. different dialogue and different reactions/outcomes)

- The battlefield now features barricades, rocks, etc. and not just a plain field

- Renown is still the only resource, but levelling up a character is a lot cheaper compared to BS1

- At level 6 characters get to choose a second ability

- There are a ton more abilities in the game now

- After you max out a stat you can now invest points into "unique talents" like 20% chance to crit, etc. These talents are the same for every hero though

- Clansmen will now forage for food. If you train them to become fighters they can no longer do that

- Almost no more actual battles with your army involved

- Enemy and hero variety has been dramatically increased. You will not only fight humans, but also feral humans, Varl, Dredge, undead Dredge and Horseborn, which varies up the battles

- Battles sometimes also have different objectives, like clearing obstruction or killing a specific enemy, etc.

- The background art has become even better and more varied: river journey on ship, travelling through cave systems, a spooky forest, etc.

- A few more cutscenes and even voice over

Generally speaking it's a great game with an interesting story and an all too familiar problem: fucking huge cliff hanger at the end, and basically the game ending too soon and you feel like something is missing. Better wait for BS 3 then...in 2018!!!! *sigh*. In the mean time, maybe you can play the story again with the other character. I'll wait for that until BS 3 arrives. The devs listened to some feedback without changing the game completely, so in the end I'd give it a 9/10.

Edit: Just played through with Rook as well. Not much difference. Generally not much difference to the story apart from some key moments, but the end will always be the same.

29300534.review:
Я долго решался поиграть в давно купленную мной вторую часть, потому что знал, что для продолжения столь блистательной игры нужен какой-то подходящий момент. Особенное время, когда ты сможешь проникнуться сказанием лучше всего.  Как никакое другое творение The Banner Saga заслуживает подобного отношения, ибо сама история создания этой игры кажется чем-то невозможным. Группа людей из известной студии не захотев продолжать создавать никчемные пустые поделки бросила все, ради того чтобы вложить свою душу в сотворение настоящего шедевра. Они прекрасно знали, на что шли, и прибыли к  весьма предсказуемому исходу — на разработку третьей части попросту нет денег.

История по-прежнему восхищает всей своей масштабностью, прекрасной мифологией и потрясающими образами. Сотворенная в восхитительном скандинавском антураже, она, так же как и раньше очаровывает происходящей в гибнущем мире историей, предоставляет сложные моральные выборы и радует глаз живописными панорамами. И хоть в некоторых местах отчетливо виден недостаток средств, разработчики все равно стараются экспериментировать, удивлять игрока и даже преподносить редкие анимационные вставки. 

Концовка вышла особо проникновенной и явно дающей понять, что вторая глава истории расставила персонажей по своим местам перед началом грандиозного финала. Я уверен, что именно в его обещанных странностях, игра всецело раскроет себя, обретая новые, удивительные грани.

Чем же все закончится? Неизвестно. Создатели героически сказали, что сделают третью часть любой ценой, даже если им понадобится выложить деньги из своего кармана.

Возможно, нам всем нужна еще одна копия The Banner Saga.

29132834.review:
As someone who (foolishly) bought the franchise pack on sale on the strength of the original game, I'd held some hope that the second would in some way improve upon or mitigate the fundamental mechanical/balance issues in the first game. 

It is instead literally more of the same. The setting is still excellent, the writing is reasonable, and the soundtrack is gorgeous. The mechanics are asinine and backwards, and the new talents you can put points into on levelup actually make the game worse by introducing RNG, the lack of which was one of the only bright spots mechanically in BS1 (woo now we can crit or have a 15% dodge chance. yay.)

If you liked BS1 you'll like this. If you weren't a fan be prepared for more of the same, culminating in a particularly dreadful and abrupt ending pitting two protagonists against eachother. 

Also if you pick or import a save as Alette, enjoy being literally unbeatable in combat since her new toy at level six is ludicrously broken. Free range 8 overwatch attacks with no limit and a knockback stapled on which ends the turns of the people she hits. Put some shields around her and watch the enemy kill itself trying to approach.

29053346.review:
One thing to understand is that Banner Saga 2 is not a separate game—this is the second chapter of the same story which will make no sense if you haven't played the original. Also, unlike the first one, where the story felt a bit unsatisfying due to you only beating a small boss (rather than getting to the bottom of the whole plight), here the game ends in a blatant cliffhanger. More important events happen outside the camera's eye, left unexplained. Honestly, it all makes me feel that it may be smarter to wait for Banner Saga 3 before picking this up.

As a continuation of Banner Saga, however, this one offers no surprises and no disappointments; it's basically the same game. Still gorgeous visuals, still wonky voiceovers, still simple but fun and challenging fights. (On the highest levels there is now actually some RNG present in them, but it works well.)

The useful part about sequels like BS2 is that they offer no decision-making to you as a buyer. If you liked the first game, this one is a must. If you didn't (or haven't played it), there's no reason to buy it. It's as simple as that.

Und wie immer hat manviel zu wenig Anerkennung und muss sich entscheiden, ob einem Charakterstufen, Items oder Verpflegung wichtiger sind. Musik ist wie immer extrem stimmungsvoll und die Grafik mit den wunderbar gezeichneten Landschaften gefällt so gut wie im ersten Teil. Klare Kaufempfehlung.

28873303.review:
Like TBS, TBS2 is a great story game with a terrible strategy game attached to it. The turn-based combat is a drawn-out slog where the best strategy is to delay every fight as long as possible to setup a full team kill, so that weakened enemies waste turns in the meantime. The game also poorly explains many of the new mechanics and skills, and fails to give proper guidance on many missions, forcing you to fail to actually figure out what the win conditions are.

The story or "Oregon Trail Lite" would be acceptable if you weren't arbitrarily punished by your decisions. There are no difficult decisions to make about what to do, because every choice is either right or wrong. You either pick the right choice and get a bonus, or you pick the wrong choice and a crucial party member is killed or half your caravan is destroyed.

---

What I originally wrote was just supposed to be a short review, so let me clarify some points. Admittedly I was melodramatic about the game destroying half your caravan and party for a bad choice. That only happens once.

Now what makes a good game? Choice.
What makes a good story game? Making you feel like your choices had meaning.
How does a story game do this? Giving the choices you didn't make, a real impact to the plot.

This is why I consider TBS + TBS2 good story games. They have several key decisions that have a major impact on the plot and give your choices real heft. Unfortunately TBS2 is still a good story game with a worse strategy game attached to it.

It's important to understand that there are two distinct parts of your strategy in TBS. The turn-based combat part, and the "Oregon Trail" part where you basically play a choose your own adventure book. The problem is that the choose your own adventure book only has a few pages where you make a meaningful decision. The other hundred or so pages are just you being rewarded or punished for a choice, and then the story continues.

Why is this a problem? When you replay a good story game, trying out the choices you didn't make the first time is rewarding. When you play a bad story game, you realize that the other choices didn't matter or just led to game over screens. TBS doesn't end the game, but it does punish you. That little plus or minus of morale or clansmen is a sign that the choice you made was either wrong or right. And if the only real choice you have is to make the right choice or the wrong choice? Your choice becomes meaningless. The game hides this of course with text, but it doesn't change the binary nature of most of the choices you make, and it muddies the key decisions that really do matter in TBS. If TBS was just a story game this could be ignored, especially because you don't get hit by a game over screen, but unfortunately TBS is also a strategy game.

What makes a good strategy game? Being able to implement clever tactics against a clever enemy. Being able to make calculated decisions to win against the adversary.

What makes a bad strategy game? Having no real indication of how your choices will affect you. Having a single correct choice instead of multiple. 

Now TBS2 actually has a solution to the problems I see in it, but before that I'll get to the turn-based combat. Now if you agree with what I said about what makes a good strategy game, you might not understand why I dislike the strategy in TBS2. 

I actually liked it. In short bites. I had fun on hard until i got halfway and decided to switch to easy and just bruteforce the fights.

The problem with the combat is that the campaign rewards cautious behavior too much. Much like in the first TBS, maiming enemies to the point of uselessness and forcing them to waste turns is still the best way to play. Now you have some more options to waste time admittedly. You have more crowd control to play "keep away" and lock down dangerous enemies until you can whittle them down into nothing, but the best strategy is still basically slow erosion broken up by a few mass cullings. The highlight of the combat is when you can basically slaughter a half dozen enemies in one go and ride out to victory. And I mean, it's great. It feels like a great way to end a fight, but when the best way to end every fight is doing that? It loses its charm along the way. Real people could be different, but the AI's only real plan is rush you until you die, which is what makes the strategy so effective in the first place.

What could fix all of this? For "Oregon Trail", if instead of being punished or rewarded for the random events, you instead had to choose how you took the hit/ gain. I.E. choose whether to save fighters or clansmen while your ships are sinking, gather extra supplies while you have time or scout ahead to avoid a battle. TBS2 has a few choices that actually adhere to this (most of them being the key ones I mentioned earlier), which makes it mind boggling to me why it wasn't just used as a format for all of them. Likewise TBS2 also fixes my problem with the turn-based combat in its survival mode, removing enemies from the turn order when they die, and giving you a double turn that allows for much more aggressive tactics and flexibility in your playstyle. Again, why wasn't that just the default, or at least an option.

Still going to buy TBS3 probably.

28853526.review:
While this game does a lot right, even going above and beyond in its predecessor's combat mechanics and building off its engaging universe, it doesn't offer a satisfying experience due to its abrupt ending, poor pacing, and rather simplistic gameplay. 

Pros:

- It may require a refresher from the first game, but BS2 has a rich world to learn about with many unique and memorable characters. 

- Great artwork and soundtrack

- Generally fun combat

- Engaging plot



Cons:

- Pacing. Throughout the game it's unclear how much food you'll need, when you'll need to spend/save renown, when heros will split and where you are in the story. It's not satisfying to suddenly save people, train fighters or buy food, etc. when there's little to form expectations. The sudden ending was extremely unsatisfying.

- Unused game mechanics. The playable partsof the game primarily consist of an Oregon Trail dynamic, dialogue options and combat. What are my unused heroes doing? Why do I need clansmen/fights other then to scavenge? Clearly things may make a difference in the next game if you decide to continue your game, but BS2 by itself doesn't offer much beyond combat scenes and journey dialogue.

- The game really depends on players carrying over knowledge, connections to characters, etc. from the first game. For this reason alone it's hard to recommend this game to anyone but people who have played the first one. While with this isn't exactly a ton to ask for an indie developer to ask for, there's the reality that this game isn't a complete whole on it's own from start to finish. 

Just a few thoughts, but I'd recommend waiting for a sale or waiting until the next game comes out to really reap the benefits of playing this game.

28793437.review:
I don't write reviews. At all. But exceptions have to be made for what is hauntingly amazing.  I loved the first one, but TBS 2 is on another level.

Gameplay wise, it's fairly simple to play, but in my experience very difficult to master (I still struggle with *fully completing* one particular boss fight in the game on the hardest difficulty.) Despite the simplicty and challenge, playing the story battles over and over again is always fresh because of the individual heroes' abilities - the mixing and matching of their skillsets and having to give kills to heroes to level them (some need more help than others, of course) brought me closer to the characters, and weren't just pieces I was moving around on a board. And it's inevitable that some heroes will by much more frequently utilised than others, some less, but I have enjoyed TBS 2 to a greater degree by putting myself through the struggle of attempting to use weaker characters - mixing and matching squads of shieldbanger varl with archers, only having human characters armed with shields to form a defensive line and buff stats while restricting movement, or playing with more support characters than slayers. 

I'm not one to complain or praise visuals because art more often than not is a *different strokes for different folks* thing in my opinion, but the art of TBS 2... I didn't want the game to end when it did, and one of the main reasons why is its visuals. Absolutely stunning by all accounts. While there are few animated scenes with characters moving about, the still depictions of the characters with their written dialogue below are just so fantastically vivid that the words come to life. Bolverk's character is truly out of the screen, for one. The silent moments between Rook and Iver. The chilling stills of Juno. Even simple details like Hakon's speech just fits the way he's so humongously built and towering over even other varl as a slayer in combat. The game can in that regard be enjoyed if played slowly, and the interactions made animate with one's mind.

The story. People liken it to Tolkien's universe, or at least from what I've seen in the other reviews. I'd beg to differ to an extent. It is after all based on Norse mythology to my knowledge, especially with the serpent's presence. So, take the carnage of Ragnarok with a Tolkien-esque twist, multiple narrative perspectives from two different caravans (including some ambiguity), and top it off with a tenderness in the moments less tense, very much made possible by the visuals. The moments when the caravan stops to rest, or has simply has to stop because they're too tired to continue. Watching the caravan make its way across the vast lands is a remarkable view and story to be told in itself. Coming across empty houses, battle-scarred villages, forgotten mine shafts, caverns, or even a death march across barren snowlands for a final stand at a ford... this is the story of TBS 2.

I bought TBS 1 on a whim just to try out an indie game that looked somewhat promising. The promise that it's delivered is far beyond expectations. It really is a world one can dive into and continuously appreciate if the time is taken or the eye is in awe of. Just get this game for god's sake it really is a bomb it's just wowza.

28777788.review:
Better than the first game definitely, this game continues last games story (which I highly recommend) but features a longer seeming story (which is nice). Combat will come naturally to veterans but might need some practice if you're new to this series. The story has some awesome twists and and secrets (some mind nukes are dropped), though the effect will be most acute for previous players. Overall I'd say this game is a good 9/10 in my book, perhaps a little expensive for those without income but well worth the investment if you enjoyed the last game. This game also features a survival mode which was a bit more dissapointing for me but is still engaging for people who loved the combat side of this game. It features a combat challenge with time limits and ever more difficult battles. It's effectively a minigame to measure how hardcore your skills are with this combat system.

Clan Improvements in BannerSaga 2:
Foraging: Villagers now forage food, if you balance fighters with clansmen just right you'll never starve.
Training challenges: The camp now gives you challenges to complete (ex: kill the spear men but only with specific attacks) which you can be rewarded for completeing.
Conscription: You can turn clansmen into soldiers! Soldiers wont forage well and eat more food, but will even the odds in war. This effect is not reversable.

Suggestions for the future of Banner Saga:
I'd personally love a scenario/sandbox mode (possibly multiplayer) where you survive as a clan that you make feeding your soldiers, training people, dealing with randomized events, and facing ever growing assaults by dredge. I understand this would be difficult but if combined with the steam modmaking community players could create some EPIC user generated settings and plots. Such a scenario mode (perhaps with some scenario creation tools) could create really interesting fan stories. 
Alternatively a charachter creation tool would also be interesting if it could be implimented, so players can put themselves in the story with individual charchter designes. This suggestion I'd argue is the easier of my two suggestions to impliment in future Banner Saga games and would still create further player engagement.

There's been some improvements in both storytelling and combat, with few downsides that I believe will be adjusted in Saga 3. It's good to see that they are trying to make things actually better and not just rely on Saga 1 system, which makes me look forward to next Saga.

Join the caravan and start your own journey.

28751515.review:
I loved Banner Saga 1 and I love Saga 2 even more. It's better in almost every aspect with the exception of even more open ending (but it's a middle part of the whole story, so I expected it to be like that). 

Core gameplay stays the same, but it's much more diverse. Developers added more unit types, skills, more type of enemies and a race of horseborn with unique skills and atributes. Another novelty they added are battlefield objectives - so not every battle requires You to kill every enemy on the field but fullfil some task instead. 

Visuals are stunning as in first saga. It's pleasant to look at. And there are more cutscenes, animations and voiced monologues to enjoy.

Without going into any details that might lead to spoilers - story was captivating and kept me hungry for more trough the whole playtrough (and because of the open ending, I'm still hungry even after finishing it). Choices still matter and some have very harsh consequences. 
You can start with one of two different main characters (based on the choice from previous installment). I have yet to discover how much different the story will be.

Those who liked the previous game will enjoy the second even more. 
I recommend to play first saga before going to second, because without it You'd be boarding a moving train.

28744563.review: Great story and follow up to the first one.

28717362.review:
The more i play of the Banner Saga, the more im reminded of Dan Simmons epic novel about the doomed Franklin Arctic Expedition "The Terror". In The Terror, Captain Francis Crozier tries desperately to save the lives of the 120 souls still alive in his command as they fend off starvation, scurvy, mutiny and hauling thousand pound sledges across Sea Ice, all while running from an unstoppable threat that is hunting and killing his men one by one. Every decision Crozier makes seems to reult in more and more deaths but the alternatives are even worse.
In the Banner Saga 2, you continue your journey as Rook, leading your caravan of fighters, clansmen and giant horned blokes as you fight off mutiny, starvation, and a relentless enemy that is hounding you literally to the ends of the earth. Every decision you make for the good of your clansmen might seem straightforward at the time but will generally wind up biting you in the ass down the line as you struggle to keep morale and supplies from running out, and your people safe from the rampaging Dredge. 

10/10 but could really use some kind of Scurvy stat for my starving clansmen
